title: Linked ValueSet - a Data Oriented Set
narrative:
A linked `ValueSet` is a fundamental building block in sprouts' data-oriented programming model.
    It represents an immutable collection of unique and ordered elements, providing an API focused on
    deriving new sets from existing ones rather than mutating state. Unlike traditional
    Java sets, all operations return new `ValueSet` instances, making it ideal for
    functional/data-oriented programming and safe concurrent usage.

    You can create a linked `ValueSet` through various factories, such as `ValueSet.ofLinked(Class<T>)`
    or `ValueSet.ofLinked(T first, T... rest)`. All operations on a linked `ValueSet` return a new instance,
    ensuring immutability and thread safety. The linked nature of the set ensures that the order of elements
    is preserved, which is particularly relevant to make iteration and stream operations more
    deterministic and easier to reason about.

features.id: Use `ValueSet.ofLinked(Class, Iterable)` to create a linked value set from an iterable.
An empty linked `ValueSet` is created by specifying the element type.

extraInfo:
A `ValueSet` needs to be created with a type to allow for better
            type safety during runtime as well as improved performance
            due to primitive specialization.
            A `ValueSet` based on the `Integer` class for example, will
            internally use a primitive `int[]` array to store the values.

features.id: A linked `ValueSet` maintains invariance with Java Set across many operations. [0]

blocks.text: Apply operations first time
Immediate invariance
Apply operations multiple times
Consistent state
We use the stream API to map both the value set and the JDK based reference set.
The mapped value set and mapped set are equal.
We use the parallel stream API to map both the value set and the reference set.
The mapped value set and JDK set are equal in terms of their contents.

operations:
new Tuple2(Operation.ADD, "apple"),
            new Tuple2(Operation.ADD, "banana"),
            new Tuple2(Operation.REMOVE, "apple")
        ]

features.id: The `removeAll(..)` methods handle different input collection types.

blocks.text: Elements are removed regardless of input collection type

features.id: You can remove items from a linked value set selectively, using `removeIf(Predicate)`. [0]

extraInfo:
You can remove elements from a value set which satisfy
            a given `Predicate`. Or in other words,
            if the `Predicate.test(Object)` method yields `true` for a particular
            element, then it will be removed, otherwise, it will remain in the
            returned set.

blocks.text: We create a linked value set and a regular JDK set containing some test elements.
We apply a predicate to both types of sets...
They contain the same elements!

elements: ['a' as char, 'x' as char, '4' as char, '#' as char]

features.id: You can keep items in a linked value set selectively, using `retainIf(Predicate)`. [0]

extraInfo:
You can keep elements in a value set which satisfy
            a given `Predicate` and have them removed otherwise. Or in other words,
            if the `Predicate.test(Object)` method yields `false` for a particular
            element, then it will be removed, otherwise, it will remain in the
            returned set.

blocks.text: We create a linked value set and a regular JDK set containing some test elements.

We apply a predicate to both types of sets...
            In case of the JDK set we use the negation of `removeIf`,
            which does the same thing effectively.
They contain he same elements!

elements: ['a' as char, 'x' as char, '4' as char, '#' as char]

features.id: The `retainAll(..)` methods work with diverse collection sources.

blocks.text: Only elements present in both collections are retained

features.id: The various `containsAll(..)` methods accurately check membership across collection types.

blocks.text: Membership checks work with all compatible collection types
code: valueSet.containsAll([] as Set) // Empty collection always returns true

features.id: operations with empty collections have no effect or clear as expected

blocks.text: Empty inputs leave set unchanged or clear appropriately
Retaining nothing clears the set

features.id: bulk operations ignore duplicate elements in input

blocks.text: Duplicates in input collections have no effect

features.id: interoperates with Tuple collections

blocks.text: Full interoperability with Tuple collections

features.id: collector works with different stream sources

blocks.text: Collecting from various stream sources
All collected sets match source contents

features.id: no-op operations return the same instance

blocks.text: Using no-op operations on the initial set does not return a new instance.
Adding existing elements does not change the set.

features.id: Use `ValueSet.classTyped(Class)` to created a typed class pointer to `ValueSet`.

extraInfo:
The `ValueSet.classTyped(Class)` may seem strange at first,
            but it is really important when you want to use the value set
            as a generic parameter type inferred from the class pointer.

            Like for example:
            ```java
                Var<ValueSet<String>> strings = Var.of(ValueSet.classTyped(String.class));
            ```

features.id: A value set can directly be created from a tuple.
Use the `sort(Comparator)` method to create a sorted value set from a linked one.

blocks.text: We sort the value set in reverse order.

features.id: The `equals` and `hashCode` implementations of a linked ValueSet works reliably after removing a large part of elements. [0]

extraInfo:
Here we test the implementation of the `equals` and `hashCode` methods exhaustively.
            This may look like an exaggerated amount of test data and equality checks, but you
            have to know that under the hood specifically the `equals` implementations are
            highly optimized to specific cases which need to be covered.

            More specifically, if there are only small differences between value set,
            we can avoid a lot of work due to two set sharing most of their branches.

blocks.text: We create randomly sorted variants of the test data:
We create two different `ValueSet` instances from the two scrambled list...
The two associations are equal!
They also have the same hash codes:
We create versions of the associations where parts are removed...
They are equal...
We make them different by adding to them...
code: var toAdd2 = subList.subList((subList.size() * 0.5) as int, subList.size()).toSet()

blocks.text: We use the following entry data source:

blocks.text: We use the following entry data source:

features.id: The `removeIf(Class)` method filters out items of the specified type while preserving the linked value set characteristics.

extraInfo:
The `removeIf(Class)` method creates a new linked value set containing only items that are NOT 
            instances of the specified type. This is useful for filtering out specific types from 
            a heterogeneous value set.

            Important behavior for linked variant:
            - The returned value set maintains the linked ordering characteristics
            - Items that are instances of the specified type (including subclasses) are removed
            - The element type of the returned value set remains the same as the original
            - The insertion order is preserved for remaining elements

blocks.text: A linked value set with mixed types
We remove all String instances
Only non-String items remain in original insertion order
We remove all Integer instances
Only non-Integer items remain in original insertion order
We remove all Number instances (including Integer and Double)
Only non-Number items remain in original insertion order

features.id: The `retainIf(Class)` method keeps only items of the specified type and returns a properly typed linked value set.

extraInfo:
The `retainIf(Class)` method creates a new linked value set containing only items that ARE 
            instances of the specified type. This is useful for extracting specific types from 
            a heterogeneous value set.

            Important behavior for linked variant:
            - Only items that are instances of the specified type (including subclasses) are retained
            - The returned value set is properly typed as ValueSet<V> where V is the specified type
            - The linked ordering characteristics are preserved in the result
            - The insertion order of retained elements is maintained

blocks.text: A linked value set with mixed types
We retain only String instances
Only String items remain in original insertion order and result is properly typed
We retain only Integer instances
Only Integer items remain in original insertion order and result is properly typed
We retain only Number instances (including both Integer and Double)
All Number items remain in original insertion order and result is properly typed

features.id: The `removeIf(Class)` method efficiently filters large heterogeneous collections while preserving linked set characteristics. [0]

extraInfo:
The `removeIf(Class)` method should efficiently handle large collections while 
            maintaining the original linked value set's characteristics. This test verifies that:

            - Large datasets are processed correctly
            - The operation maintains performance characteristics
            - The result preserves the linked ordering of the original set
            - Insertion order is maintained for remaining elements

            This is particularly important for data processing pipelines where linked value sets 
            might contain thousands of heterogeneous elements and order matters.

blocks.text: A linked value set with a large collection of mixed-type items
We remove all instances of the specified type
The result contains only non-matching items with preserved linked characteristics

features.id: The `retainIf(Class)` method efficiently extracts typed subsets from large heterogeneous collections while preserving order. [0]

extraInfo:
The `retainIf(Class)` method should efficiently extract homogeneous subsets 
            from large heterogeneous collections while preserving the linked ordering.
            This test verifies that:

            - Large datasets are processed correctly with proper type filtering
            - The returned value set is properly typed
            - Type safety is maintained throughout the operation
            - Linked ordering characteristics are preserved
            - Insertion order of retained elements is maintained

            This is crucial for type-safe data extraction in scenarios where you need to 
            work with specific subtypes from mixed collections and order matters.

features.id: Edge cases for `removeIf(Class)` and `retainIf(Class)` methods are handled correctly in linked value sets.

blocks.text: An empty linked value set
We try to remove items from an empty set
The empty set is returned unchanged
We try to retain items in an empty set
The empty set is returned unchanged
A linked value set where no items match the filter criteria for removal
We try to remove String instances from an Integer set
The set is returned unchanged
We try to retain String instances from an Integer set
An empty String linked set is returned
A linked value set where all items match the filter criteria for retention
We retain String instances from a String set
The set is returned unchanged (but may be a new instance)
We remove Object instances from a String set (all items are instances)
An empty linked set is returned

features.id: Linked value set type filtering preserves insertion order across complex operations

extraInfo:
This test verifies that the linked value set maintains proper insertion order
            across multiple type filtering operations, ensuring that the order semantics
            are preserved even when performing complex filtering sequences.

blocks.text: A linked value set with carefully ordered mixed types
We perform sequential type filtering operations
code: var step1 = orderedSet.retainIf(String)  // Keep only strings
var step2 = orderedSet.removeIf(Number)  // Remove all numbers from original
var step3 = step2.retainIf(String)       // Should be same as step1

blocks.text: All operations preserve the logical ordering
